(1 comment)
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 82897c35761f505c2b881f72c61f726f7d562692

This repo initially had a clang-tidy, but then we removed it when we added the yaml files for the D-Bus inteface, since clang-tidy was complaining about the generated files. See here: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/48587

We should be able to put the clang-tidy back now.
Gotcha.  Ideally that's something we should solve in phosphor-dbus-interfaces at some point so we generate "correct" code, but that's not your problem in this scope.

sounds good. 
I don't think anything is required to change in eStorageD
This actually looks like you forgot to check an error code.  ioctl can fail, which needs checked.
fd.ioctl handles those errors

yep, (what William said) stdplus gets it handles it here in the
 https://github.com/openbmc/stdplus/blob/1151c6d3d93369f16ccedd16dbb410ec2c59cfa5/src/stdplus/fd/impl.cpp#L155

and the marco is here
https://github.com/openbmc/stdplus/blob/1151c6d3d93369f16ccedd16dbb410ec2c59cfa5/src/stdplus/util/cexec.hpp#L38
ACK.
Why did you comment this out? Do you plan to enable it later?

We use macros, defined by a meson generated file. 
We should fix this, but I wanted to limit the invasive of this one change
You're referring to estoraged_conf.hpp, right? That file is listed in clang-ignore. Does clang-tidy still complain even with clang-ignore?
yes, it creates the error when the defines are used.

Could we put a TODO comment here to get rid of this in the future?

Otherwise, could it be that meson seems to use .clang-format-ignore file? https://mesonbuild.com/Code-formatting.html

i don't think clang-tidy supports a ignore file.

With that said, that's the wrong solution, if we have macros that we know we want to clean up, but maybe can't right now, we should be adding a

cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage.AllowedRegexp to the clang-tidy file, so we don't totally disable the check.  Something similar in your file to this in dbus-sensors:

https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/5cf66dfc62ccf0c2648ad0f8c3fdf2673751a579/.clang-tidy#L261

With that said, I'm totally fine with this commit taking an incremental approach to turning checks on, but the AllowedRegexp should be in a much closer change than actually removing the macros.

Also, take a look at how we solved this in bmcweb.  Basically you template the file and use set10 instead of set, and you can generate to typesafe stuff.

Another thing to keep in mind, if you comment out one line in this file, in practice, it looks like it's commenting out the rest of the tests, because there's for sure things that should've failed in this.
Nvm on the last sentence.  Was looking at the wrong diff.
done, this cppcoreguidelines-macro-usage.AllowedRegexp  worked perfectly
Is there a reason why these aren't part the class anymore?

clang-tidy gave me an error.
It told me not use arrays of chars, but use std::arrays.
I did not want to do that, so I switched to strings, but they had to be moved out side the class.
Okay, why did the strings need to be moved? Does "static constexpr std::string" not work? You might need to use "static constexpr std::string_view".
it look like auto uses const char * for strings.

Technically these std::string declarations would also fail the https://clang.llvm.org/extra/clang-tidy/checks/cppcoreguidelines-interfaces-global-init.html check had we turned it on, because std::string has to construct before main, and could throw before main.

auto works (although I'm a firm believe that it makes code harder to read and debug).  Explicitly declaring these constexpr char * would also be another solution.
switch to const char*, because I agree with Ed.
I agree, switching to const char *
Patchset 1 had a bunch of automated changes to naming and other things.  The newest patchset doesn't.

Drive by comment (please don't fix it in this patch) unit tests are supposed to be units, and shouldn't rely on another file existing, or a particular order to succeed.  This file should be cleaned up at the end of the test that creates it, ideally via a passed in /tmp/<guid> directory so we can have two copies of the tests running at once without.

Not super important to fix, just FYI.

I am not a google mock expert, but I believe this file is created for every test, in the setup member (line 62) the EStoragedTest class. And then destroyed for every test in tear down (line 98)

Most of the time we want a file there for test. However, in this test we don't want the file, so we remove it, then add it back so tear down works.

But agree, we need to append the guid to the name of the file, so we can run n of these test in parallel.

Understood.  FWIW, this is why I'm not a huge fan of set classes for tests, because it leads to stuff like this where, if handled in a method, would be easy to switch on and off.

Not a big deal.
yeah, the test class was not obvious to me at first.
Thanks for looking this over
I don't think you need this file anymore?
good call, removed
This is no longer relevant to the commit.
fixed
Thanks for taking a look
Should we at least log the exception that occurred? Or does that happen automatically?
Hmm that's a good question. I guess the program exiting with -2 may be enough signal when it gets logged in journalctl? (not entirely sure).
Yeah, you should print out a log message. Also, error return codes from main generally should be positive <100
Added log message, and returning positive 2.
Shouldn't we print the details of the exception?
I guess we would have to catch exception instead of ... then right? (or can we somehow get the exception from the ...?)

Yeah, I think we would need to catch (const std::exception& e). I don't know if there's a difference between that and catch (...)

At any rate, I don't mean to hold up this CL if you don't think this is necessary.
I think it's a nice to have for sure - let's fix this up real quick and merge this in :)
sounds good, the code will now print the exception it caught.
Thanks for looking this over
